meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! It's time to dive into the crypt-astic world of Cryptmaster, an indie game that's got everyone from Slant Magazine to Press Start Australia singing its praises. As a seasoned grok (that's gamer-speak for "I'm familiar with good games"), I'll give you the lowdown on what makes this game tick.

First off, let me say that Cryptmaster is no ordinary dungeon crawler. It takes the genre and gives it a linguistic twist, asking players to use their typing skills to progress through its mysterious world. That's right, folks – in Cryptmaster, you're not just hacking and slashing your way through monsters; you're solving puzzles and cracking codes using nothing but your wits (and your keyboard).

Now, I know what you're thinking: "Has this reviewer gone mad? A game that's all about typing can't be fun!" But trust me, friends, Cryptmaster is a revelation. It takes the frustrations of real-time typing – yes, those pesky moments when you're trying to type out a critical phrase while avoiding monster attacks – and turns them into an integral part of the gameplay experience.

But don't just take my word for it. The critics are raving about Cryptmaster's unique blend of education and entertainment. Slant Magazine praised its "real-time typing" as "trying to be original," while Hardcore Gamer noted that the game's "language-based mechanics" make it a refreshing change of pace from your average dungeon crawler.

So what does all this mean? Well, for one thing, it means that Cryptmaster is a game that will challenge even the most skilled typists. But more importantly, it means that this indie title is a breath of fresh air in an industry that often favors spectacle over substance.

In short, if you're looking for a game that's got brains as well as brawn, look no further than Cryptmaster. It may not be perfect – the combat can feel like a chore at times, and some players might get frustrated with the real-time typing – but it's definitely worth trying out.

So grab your keyboard (and maybe a pair of earplugs for those pesky bug sounds) and get ready to join me in Cryptmaster's world of cryptic puzzles and gallows humor. Hippo Penny says: this game is a must-play indie!
